content.text:
# War of Vesosis and Tanausis

The War of Vesosis and Tanausis is described in Jordanes' Getica, a controversial account of the Goths as happening in remote antiquity when Vesosis, king of the Egyptians, made war against them. Their queen at that time was Tanausis.
In a battle at the river Phasis in Colchis (modern Georgia), Tanausis, queen of the Goths, met Vesosis, king of the Egyptians, and there inflicted a severe defeat upon him, pursuing him even to Egypt.
According to Arne SÃ¸by Christensen Jordanes assumed that the Scythians were the Goths and their all women army were the Amazons. The war seems to be a retelling of an alleged war between the Scythians and Egyptians told by Orosius with Jordanes recasting a Scythian king as a queen of the Goths.
The War of Vesosis and Tanausis is a combination of transcription errors and fantasy.
